etymologies: Middle English: from up+ on, suggested by Old Norse upp á

notes.text: The preposition upon has the same core meaning as the preposition on. Upon is sometimes more formal than on, however, and is preferred in the phrases once upon a time and upon my word, and in uses such as row upon row of seats and Christmas is almost upon us

crossReferenceMarkers: more formal term for on, especially in abstract senses

examples.text: it was based upon two principles
a school's dependence upon parental support
